whatIs.title: What is Middle English Translator Studio

examples.title: Translation Examples
examples.description: See how modern texts transform into Middle English. From legal documents to literary passages, VibeTrans offers accurate translations with dialect and period precision.

items.alt:
Example 1: Basic greeting translation

Modern: 'Hello, how are you today?'
Middle English: 'Hail, hou art thou today?'

Explanation: Middle English greetings used 'hail' instead of 'hello', and the verb 'art' (are) with the pronoun 'thou' (you) reflects the period's grammar structure.
items.name: Basic Greeting Translation

items.alt:
Example 2: Literary passage

Modern: 'The knight rode through the forest on his noble steed.'
Middle English: 'The knyght rood thurgh the forest on his noble stede.'

Explanation: Note the spelling variations like 'knyght' and 'thurgh', typical of Middle English orthography, where standardized spelling did not yet exist.
items.name: Literary Passage Translation

items.alt:
Example 3: Religious text

Modern: 'May God bless you and keep you safe.'
Middle English: 'May God blesse thee and kepe thee sauf.'

Explanation: Religious texts show the use of 'thee' (you) and archaic verb forms like 'kepe' (keep), reflecting Middle English's formal religious register.
items.name: Religious Text Translation

items.alt:
Example 4: Legal document

Modern: 'The agreement between both parties shall be honored.'
Middle English: 'The acordaunce bitwene bothe parties schal be honoured.'

Explanation: Legal Middle English used formal vocabulary like 'acordaunce' and 'bitwene', showing the French influence on legal terminology of the period.
items.name: Legal Document Translation

items.alt:
Example 5: Daily conversation

Modern: 'Where are you going this morning?'
Middle English: 'Whider goost thou this morwen?'

Explanation: Middle English used 'whider' (whither) for 'where to', and 'morwen' instead of 'morning', demonstrating everyday vocabulary differences.
items.name: Daily Conversation Translation

items.alt:
Example 6: Scholarly text

Modern: 'The study of ancient wisdom brings great knowledge.'
Middle English: 'The studie of auncient wisdom bryngeth greet knowleche.'

Explanation: Academic Middle English shows French-influenced vocabulary like 'auncient' and the verb ending '-eth' in 'bryngeth' (brings), typical of third-person singular forms.
items.name: Scholarly Text Translation

items.title: Middle English Spelling Chaos
items.description: In the Middle English era, spelling was a free-for-all. The same word could have over 50 different variations. This lack of standardization makes translating Middle English a real challenge for modern tools.

items.title: Girls and Boys in Middle English
items.description: Did you know the word ‘girl’ in Middle English didn’t mean what it does today? Back then, it referred to a child of any gender. The current female-only meaning developed much later in the English language.
